t: Acts 26
Then*p Agrippa said unto Paul, Thou art permitted to speak for thyself. Then Paul stretched forth the hand, and answered for himself:
I*p think myself happy, king Agrippa, because I shall answer for myself this day before thee touching all the things whereof I am accused of the Jews:
Especially*p because I know thee to be expert in all customs and questions which are among the Jews: wherefore I beseech thee to hear me patiently.
My*p manner of life from my youth, which was at the first among mine own nation at Jerusalem, know all the Jews;
Which*p knew me from the beginning, if they would testify, that after the most straitest sect of our religion I lived a Pharisee.
And*p now I stand and am judged for the hope of the promise made of God unto our fathers:
Unto*p which promise our twelve tribes, instantly serving God day and night, hope to come. For which hope's sake, king Agrippa, I am accused of the Jews.
Why*p should it be thought a thing incredible with you, that God should raise the dead?
I*p verily thought with myself, that I ought to do many things contrary to the name of Jesus of Nazareth.
Which*p thing I also did in Jerusalem: and many of the saints did I shut up in prison, having received authority from the chief priests; and when they were put to death, I gave my voice against them.
And*p I punished them oft in every synagogue, and compelled them to blaspheme; and being exceedingly mad against them, I persecuted them even unto strange cities.
Whereupon*p as I went to Damascus with authority and commission from the chief priests,
At*p midday, O king, I saw in the way a light from heaven, above the brightness of the sun, shining round about me and them which journeyed with me.

And*p when we were all fallen to the earth, I heard a voice speaking unto me, and saying in the Hebrew tongue, Saul,*r Saul,*r why*r persecutest*r thou*r me?*r it*r is*r hard*r for*r thee*r to*r kick*r against*r the*r pricks.*r
And*p I said, Who art thou, Lord? And he said, I*r am*r Jesus*r whom*r thou*r persecutest.*r

But*rp rise,*r and*r stand*r upon*r thy*r feet:*r for*r I*r have*r appeared*r unto*r thee*r for*r this*r purpose,*r to*r make*r thee*r a*r minister*r and*r a*r witness*r both*r of*r these*r things*r which*r thou*r hast*r seen,*r and*r of*r those*r things*r in*r the*r which*r I*r will*r appear*r unto*r thee;*r
Delivering*rp thee*r from*r the*r people,*r and*r from*r the*r Gentiles,*r unto*r whom*r now*r I*r send*r thee,*r

To*rp open*r their*r eyes,*r and*r to*r turn*r them*r from*r darkness*r to*r light,*r and*r from*r the*r power*r of*r Satan*r unto*r God,*r that*r they*r may*r receive*r forgiveness*r of*r sins,*r and*r inheritance*r among*r them*r which*r are*r sanctified*r by*r faith*r that*r is*r in*r me.*r
Whereupon,*p O king Agrippa, I was not disobedient unto the heavenly vision:

But*p shewed first unto them of Damascus, and at Jerusalem, and throughout all the coasts of Judaea, and then to the Gentiles, that they should repent and turn to God, and do works meet for repentance.
For*p these causes the Jews caught me in the temple, and went about to kill me.
Having*p therefore obtained help of God, I continue unto this day, witnessing both to small and great, saying none other things than those which the prophets and Moses did say should come:
That*p Christ should suffer, and that he should be the first that should rise from the dead, and should shew light unto the people, and to the Gentiles.
And*p as he thus spake for himself, Festus said with a loud voice, Paul, thou art beside thyself; much learning doth make thee mad.
But*p he said, I am not mad, most noble Festus; but speak forth the words of truth and soberness.
For*p the king knoweth of these things, before whom also I speak freely: for I am persuaded that none of these things are hidden from him; for this thing was not done in a corner.
King*p Agrippa, believest thou the prophets? I know that thou believest.
Then*p Agrippa said unto Paul, Almost thou persuadest me to be a Christian.
And*p Paul said, I would to God, that not only thou, but also all that hear me this day, were both almost, and altogether such as I am, except these bonds.
And*p when he had thus spoken, the king rose up, and the governor, and Bernice, and they that sat with them:
And*p when they were gone aside, they talked between themselves, saying, This man doeth nothing worthy of death or of bonds.
Then*p said Agrippa unto Festus, This man might have been set at liberty, if he had not appealed unto Caesar.
